Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Dragan, please see my comments. And how to select UART function, please see my email:

From: Quan Xiong 
Sent: Monday, September 22, 2014 11:38 AM
To: Victor He; Mark Yan; Dragan Marinkovic; Traving Chen; Yoking Wang
Subject: RE: Console functionality in LK

Yes, when UART is configured to CONSOLE function, then this UART should be supported in LK. It’s easy for us to support this as we can get UART configuration value from shared memory in LK. 

But please note that in Yocto, in order to be compatible with previous operation, UART2 is set to CONSOLE by default.

So here is the logic for CONOSLE selected:

If(UART1_CONFIG == 16)
{
  UART1 is selected as CONOSLE function
}
Else if( (UART2_CONFIG == 0) || (UART2_CONFIG == 16))
{
  UART2 is selected as CONSOLE function
}

Regards,
Quan

So my suggestion is, when UART is selected as CONSOLE function, then it can be used for log printing in LK.

Regards,
Quan

comments.message: we should use the UART configuration value to decide which UART is selected to print log. Just like in Linux kernel, when UART function is CONSOLE, then LK can print log on this UART. to use Macro to decide UART usage is not a good way.

If we don't consider the UART service and just used macro here, it may lead to a known exception, such as if the UART is used for AT command, when the APP in LK, some unexpected data will be send to user interface. It must be configured.
just as previous comment, not to use Macro to select UART for log printing. we should use run-time selecting by checking shared memory of UART configuration.

You are using SIGTERM to kill hostappd. If for some reason that app is locked up, it won't be killed. And the only signal to try is SIGKILL. If that does not work, you have to reboot the system.

This is not what I meant. It would be useful if you could try your changes before they are submitted for review. There are few problems here:

* killall may return 0 even if running app is not killed. Try to kill:

has to say. YOu have to do 'ps | grep ...' .

* You are not checking if your process is already "zombie", in which case you can't kill it. You have to do something like:

    ps | grep 'cat /dev/nmea' | grep -v grep | awk '{ print $4 }'

* You are not checking if process is dead after 'killall -SIGKILL', and you have to do that (please see my comments in patchset 4). If not killed, you have to reboot because, something went terribly wrong.

commits.commitMessage:
ticket:1514 msm_otg: suspend/resume on cable unplug/plug

The expected behaviour of Legato is to suspend when the Head Unit
connected over the USB OTG interface disconnects or performs a
runtime suspend of its USB peripheral. This set of patches
implements the desired functionality in conformance to Android
autosleep.

The patch set consists of three patches:

5038-msm_otg-stay-awake-to-process-state-change.patch: uses the USB
PHY's wakeup source to protect OTG's state machine from inadvertently
suspending while there are events pending. This fix is mandatory if
autosleep is used.

5039-msm_otg-use-wakeup-soruce-in-msm_otg_platform_data.patch: enables
the wakeup_source (previously wake_lock) in msm_otg's private data.
This patch is needed if USB cable plug/unplug is the ultimate and
only criterion for resuming/suspending. If other components are
involved in the decision, then the need for this wakeup_source is
debatable and a user-space wakeup_source may be better.

5040-msm_otg-suspend-resume-on-cable-unplug-plug.patch: links the
wakeup source from previous patch to cable plug/unplug events.
The patch has some assumptions/limitations described in its commit
message and should be removed when a comprehensive solution for
USB OTG power management is implemented.

FIXME: Please read this commit message and commit messages in members
of this patch set to decide if patches need to be revised, included
or dropped after comprehensive USB OTG power management is implemented.

Change-Id: Ib97842bc506cb62dfbde47ecbd07c03f4f150abd
Signed-off-by: Zoran Markovic <zmarkovic@sierrawiereless.com>
commits.subject: ticket:1514 msm_otg: suspend/resume on cable unplug/plug

Does this actually set the config item on?
The normal way in Yocto to modify the kernel config items is to add a cfg file (a config snippet) which is automatically applied, but this actually patches a KConfig file directly.

commits.commitMessage:
SBM 15258: mtd: msm_nand: No USB function after hundreds of power cycle test at low temperture

This check-in to fix an issue that MTD driver reports EUCLEAN error too early.
Before the change default setting of MTD bit flip threshold is 1 regardless of the ECC strength of target NAND. In this case when one page has more than 1 bit flip, MTD driver will report an EUCLEAN error to YAFFS2 and it will sometimes cause YAFFS2 chunk read fail and then system halt, even those bit flips have been corrected by NAND FLASH controller.
This check-in will let MTD driver detect NAND flash ECC strength first. If NAND flash uses 8-bit ECC MTD driver will change the bit flip threshold form 1 to 6.

Change-Id: I3ffed6a98f1174cdfdfb0e2c119fc664c8346bb1
commits.subject: SBM 15258: mtd: msm_nand: No USB function after hundreds of power cycle test at low temperture

Patch Set 1:

I have some questions on this patch:
1. Is this patch supposed to work with both Yocto 1.4 and 1.6 ?
2. Do we still need wake-lock patches from Wind-River, along with this patch in order for full LPM (auto sleep etc.) to function, or this patch along will do ?

Patch Set 1:

> I have some questions on this patch:
 > 1. Is this patch supposed to work with both Yocto 1.4 and 1.6 ?
 > 2. Do we still need wake-lock patches from Wind-River, along with
 > this patch in order for full LPM (auto sleep etc.) to function, or
 > this patch along will do ?

This patch is expected to work with all Yocto versions going forward. It is independent from the auto-sleep/wakelock patches because they handle different use cases: 
1. The auto-sleep/wakelock patch is intended for cases when all wakelocks are released and the system can be fully suspended.
2. This patch is intended for cases where e.g. a wakelock is held so the system could not go into full suspend, but the CPU does not have anything to do. In that case, the CPU could go into deep idle state to conserve power.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

OK,thanks.

commits.commitMessage:
ticket:1194 Enable deeper idle states for MSM9615

There were two issues preventing MSM9615 from entering idle states
deeper than WFI:
1. A bug in msm_pm_idle_prepare() that always selected idle state 0.
2. The android gadget and android usb devices forced the PM QoS
level to WFI.

This patch fixed both issues above and allows the A5 to go into
deeper idle states, namely POWER_COLLAPSE_STANDALONE and
POWER_COLLAPSE. Should there be a need for better responsiveness
in the future, this can be handled by setting PM QoS level from
user space.

Change-Id: I9451e3b1ef12ad5cc64ba3e1718f8e9e5b99c9dd
Signed-off-by: Zoran Markovic <zmarkovic@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: ticket:1194 Enable deeper idle states for MSM9615

commits.commitMessage:
TRAC-1547: disable deferred resume of HCD bus

HSIC driver configured the HCD bus for deferred resume. This left
the HCD bus in a "resuming" state forever, preventing subsequent
system suspend requests, as described in TRAC 1547 and (possibly)
1556. This is also the root cause of ethernet crash and suspend
failures described in TRAC 1227.

Clearing the "skip_resume" flag causes the HCD bus to resume in the
foreground, thus rendering all connected devices operational.

Change-Id: Ica7c377e1e08fbad7a1df6b3918b682f5e50dd74
Signed-off-by: Zoran Markovic <zmarkovic@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: TRAC-1547: disable deferred resume of HCD bus

Patch Set 7:

we may need also to support UART in LK. add this notes here:

From: Quan Xiong 
Sent: Monday, September 22, 2014 11:38 AM
To: Victor He; Mark Yan; Dragan Marinkovic; Traving Chen; Yoking Wang
Subject: RE: Console functionality in LK

Yes, when UART is configured to CONSOLE function, then this UART should be supported in LK. It’s easy for us to support this as we can get UART configuration value from shared memory in LK. 

But please note that in Yocto, in order to be compatible with previous operation, UART2 is set to CONSOLE by default.

So here is the logic for CONOSLE selected:

If(UART1_CONFIG == 16)
{
  UART1 is selected as CONOSLE function
}
Else if( (UART2_CONFIG == 0) || (UART2_CONFIG == 16))
{
  UART2 is selected as CONSOLE function
}

Regards,
Quan

yes, to used by application, needs to set UART function to "APP"(17).
UART2 is set to CONSOLE by default. but we open UART2 function to application usage, customer may need to use UART2 for other purpose. it's more flexiable to configurate in this way.
You are using this at more than one place. Please, move common defs to run.env (located at meta-swi-extras/meta-swi-{src,bin}/recipes/sierra/files/run.env and source it in files that need these defs.

This won't work because you have no console and text will go nowhere. Please, use swi_log provided in run.env . The same goes for all similar constructs in this file.

If I understand correctly "DM" concerns the diag protocol, a QCom thing to trace & do things with QXDM for instance, not a console/text thing. It also shows as "DM" in Windows if diag function is added to usb.

Is that what you understood Dragan ?
Done
This belongs to sierra-initscripts.bb, since it's more system related.

Copyright (c) 2014 Sierra Wireless Inc.

I wold still like to change this unusual config. I've never seen two console statements on the kernel command line and it is guaranteed to break parsing of /proc/cmdline . I would propose changing "console=" to "try_console_0=" and "try_console_1=". This way it is clear what this command line is all about.

Also, please try to pass only one console on the command line and see if it works (it should work, correct?)..
it doesn't work for the other one which not in the command line. we need to add both of them.
How would final inittab look like? You can describe it here.

we should use the same as the one under "poky/meta/recipes-core/sysvinit/sysvinit-inittab/" and we can add our own configuration(like run_getty.sh) to it.

line 35 to 44 is generated during building, if not to delete these lines, then there would be duplicated lines in the final inittab generated.

Instead of doing this, you should be more sophisticated and be certain that UART functionality is controlled by modem side (e.g. unique 64-bit number or some kind of SHA checksum calculation). This way, bit flip in RAM could give you false positive (RAM has Mean Time Between Failures, externally generated electrical noise could be the problem as well).

yes, usually for shared memory, we would add another object which record the opposite value, then to check if(a = ~b) to check if there is bit flip. this needs to change both SBL2 and Yocto, so I think we can address it and improve it later. because this function only called one time during boot, it's not so critical to use the mechanism you mentioned.
Are we going to allow console on UART1 as well? I do not see why not. It may never be set, but we have a way out.

UART1 also can be set as CONSOLE if uart_func[line] == 16.
these lines only to set UART2 as default CONSOLE when shared memory not supported on SBL2 or when UART2 function set to 0.

both UART1 and UART2 function can be set by !MAPUART.

If script dies, getty will be re-spawned. Do you have a guard in run_getty.sh to prevent system from spawning two instances of getty?

only the prvious one exit then system will spwn a new run_getty.sh.
but we need to solve the respawning issue in this condition: when no uart mapped to console, run_getty.sh will exit immediately, then system will respawn run_getty.sh immediately. so my solution is that in this condition, let run_getty.sh sleep forever.
OK.

So we can't have a console both on UART1 and UART2 ?
If we specify both as CONSOLE, that's what we're asking, but it seems like an impossible situation according to this 'else if'.

yes. this is a good question. in fact, shell can be used both on UART1 and UART2 ports. currently when both ports configured as CONSOLE function, only UART1 can used as CONSOLE. to configure both Ports to use CONSOLE, we need to use two seperate script, such as run_getty1.sh and run_getty2.sh. another problem is that only one UART can be used to print kernel message. So in this way, when both UART1 and UART2 configured to CONSOLE function, both of these two ports can type SHELL command. but only UART1 can print kernel message. If we agree in this way, I'll change the behavior.

Rather than having two scripts, you could instanciate this same script twice with an argument in inittab:

S:2345:respawn:/etc/init.d/run_getty.sh 1

S:2345:respawn:/etc/init.d/run_getty.sh 2

(sample arguments only, maybe it would be better to specify UART1 and ttyHSL0, I don't know ...)

As for kernel messages, I agree.

We are talking about two different things:
* Console for kernel messages of which there can be only one (kernel console).
* Getty console where users can interact with the platform (user console).

Usually, kernel console and user console are different. However, in embedded systems they are usually the same, because kernel messages are collected into the ring buffer and will stop showing up on the console once init takes over.

Bertrand, I think that we are OK if we have just one user serial console. In this case, we do not have to change this behavior.
Agreed. and please note that in our solution, when both UART1 and UART2 set to fucntion CONSOLE(16), then only UART1 can be used as CONSOLE.
That will make this process wake up every 20 seconds isn't it ? What about a 'read /dev/null' without the while instead ?

Bertrand,

We cannot use 'read' because it's bash built-in, and we are going to get rid of bash on the target. Quan, you can use any blocking read for which you are sure it will never happen, like:

    cat /dev/tty63
use /sbin/getty 38400 tty1 to block the script.
Why is this line commented ? Why is it here ?
OK, I'll delete it.

Do
    cat /dev/tty63

or similar. That way, process will never exit, but it is not wasting system resources.
used /sbin/getty 38400 tty1 to block the script.
Probably, needs to be removed.
Done
What happens if we select UART for app usage (17) ? Won't the Linux console interfere with the pure app usage ? Is there something (in LK maybe) to restrict this ?

when UART is configured as APP(17), then this UART will not be used as console. it doensn't affect the console funtion. the restriction  is implemented in UART driver in linux kernel.  please see the patch for details.

What is going to happen if you have just one console specified. For example:

    ... console=ttyHSL0 ...

and UART1 is selected to be Linux kernel and user console? Would that work?

if only one ttyHSL0 is specified for console, then kernel message can't print to UART2 event it's configured to function console(16). to Print kernel message to UART,  must meet two conditions: first it must in command line, second is that it's configured to function 16(for UART2 when it configured to 0, it's reserved to CONSOLE).

so to answer your question, when only "console=ttyHSL0" and uart1 is selected to be Linux kernel and user console, then it works. but when UART2 is selected to be kernel and user console, then only user console works, kenerl console not work as no COMMOND Line "console=ttyHSL1".

when I use cat /dev/zero to do test, I found this will also block UART getty process. but when I use cat /dev/tty1, it works well, so I changed to cat /dev/tty1.

my test case:
in inittab, to respawn two run_getty instances, one is to start getty on UART2, the other is to run "cat /dev/zero", then we can see that when cat /dev/zeror running, UART2 can't type any SHELL command. but if I change the blocked operation to "cat /dev/tty1", then SHELL works well on UART2.

yes, I have done this test. Not in SSH, but in the adb shell(shoud be the same with SSH). after killing the run_getty.sh, it can restart again. it works as our expected.

I do not think it works, I just tried it and I can't log back in. Also I have additional gettys running. Can you please do the following to simulate the death of script:

msm_hsic: suspend device in full system suspend

This patch fixes entry ehci_msm_hsic device into low power mode
during full system suspend. Essentially msm_hsic_pm_suspend()
never triggered a suspend of the device, but just checked if
it is in low power mode. This is now fixed by adding a call to
msm_hsic_suspend().

Hi Quan,

sorry there was an issue with the vote from ctogroup, as the build server suffered a reboot today and something went wrong, thus the failed build/not verified issue.

I had retriggered the build, but it's seems you submitted a patch multiple times. Is this your final revision for now ? (auto-build is quite long, about 3 hours, and is retriggered every time there is a new patch).

Also, it seems you are pushing your commit for review each time with a new "Change-Id", which is what Gerrit is using to follow changeset and new patch revisions. Could you please keep the same change-id on every revision of your patch, as to track history and progress ?

If you happen not to know how to do this, please have a look at "git commit --amend" and make sure you installed the commit hook: https://trac.legato/wiki/HowTo/SoftwareConfigurationManagement#Underthehood (step 2).

Thanks,
Bertrand

Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

No need to do do this step, please create early startup script. However, there is another problem which you need to solve: if getty dies or user exits, getty will not be restarted and the console is lost until system is rebooted.

You have to find the way to tell init to restart getty.

--Dragan

Patch Set 3: No score

What we should do is the following:
* Start monit from inittab (https://mmonit.com/monit/). It can monitor multiple processes. This will also ensure that monit is restarted if it dies for any reason.
* Configure monit to start and monitor getty. If getty dies or exits, monit will restart it.

I already raised ticket to add monit to Yocto: https://softwiki:444/ticket/1360 .

comments.message:
Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

For backup only, still need some work.
Uploaded patch set 2.
Uploaded patch set 3.
Uploaded patch set 4.

Patch Set 4:

What is the effect of the changes? What output is generated that is different?

Does this allow us to generate an installable SDK for /opt/swi? And is it only for internal use or are the proprietary parts removed?

Patch Set 4:

The toolchain provided by this actually works, it can be used to build Legato.

Generated toolchains can be obtained here: http://frilm-lnxlegato01:8080/job/YoctoDylanMdm9x15/276/artifact/delivery/

This one doesn't contain any proprietary headers.

Actually, this patch contains multiple parts:
1. Provide a toolchain recipe (inheriting meta-toolchain) + some packages required by Legato
2. Split packages than contain proprietary headers in two parts:
- the -dev one (qmi-dev for instance) with library used for compilation
- the -qcomdev one (qmi-qcomdev) with headers, which are usually contained in a -dev package
3. Provide a new distro: that's the only way I found to redefine SDKPATH to /opt/swi/y14-ext, this is a setting that must be set to "poky-swi-ext" in conf/local.conf

I did a grep on the toolchain 'sysroots' folder and just realized it still contains some proprietary scripts in sysroots/armv7a-vfp-neon-poky-linux-gnueabi/etc (but there is no more proprietary headers in sysroots/armv7a-vfp-neon-poky-linux-gnueabi/usr/include for instance). Since these files are actually also on the rootfs we released, maybe that's also something we ought to look out even for the rootfs itself.

I kept the "-ext" suffix to eventually develop a "-int" one that would contain proprietary stuff.

Patch Set 4:

I had another look for initscripts under copyright.
And still, I'm not sure what to do about this: are we authorized to ship these files in the rootfs ?

Patch Set 4:

Just a general comment: why we are installing a toolchain onto opt? It requires root privs. Unless it's installed on the server, it's far better to install it relative to user's home dir.

Patch Set 4:

There is some issue with the sysroot and it's not actually relocatable, so if we extract by default in $USER/.swi/toolchain/ , for now it won't be able to find libraries.

This is clearly a bug, that's actually detailed in this ticket ( https://softwiki.sierrawireless.local:444/ticket/429 ). Toolchains from mingw don't have that problem for instance.

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

Hi everyone,

This check-in to fix sbm14659 modem can't bootup after flash cutom Yocto image with fastboot

Since test found this issue just happen in AR7 image; WP7 and AR7 not DR version have not this issue,  beginning  we think it’s data reliability related issue. But debug found the bootfast download base addr is 0x45800000, it’s not correct(according to latest 1G/2G ram layout it should be 0x45c00000), and  this cause APP RAM address is conflicted with modem side RAM address. After manually change the download_base to 0x45c000000,  re-compile APP and re-test fastboot download kernel, modem can boot up normally.

Root Cause
wrong fastboot download base addr setting 

Solution
Correct the fastboot download base addr setting in compile script 

Thanks,
Stan

Testing 
Device tested: <AR7550>
OS used during verification: <Windows7>
Connection Manager & version: <Not applicable> 

Before fix this bug, get bootfast download base addr:
  download_base = 0x45800000 = end_of_ram+0x4000000 ->

After fix this bug, get bootfast download base addr:
  download_base = 0x45C00000 = end_of_ram+0x4400000 ->

Test procedure to produce this bug or to verify having fixed this bug：
1) enter adb shell and switch app to fastboot mode
2) using fastboot download kernel to flash
3) exit fastboot mode and check modem whether can boot up

1. Test using fastboot to download QCT kernel

Hi Dragan,
I would rather not do this, reasons:
1. the same changes have been verified with QTI Linux on AR7556. And the changes are very straightforward and should be low risk for Yocto
2. we can commit this as it is then do follow-up test when Yocto supports AR7556 with 1G/2G memory and fix possible issues in case any.

So i think add this notice in Gerrit is adequate, please consider.

HI Victor,

The commit messages reflect the state of the feature at the time of the commit. If you test your commited feature at some point of time in the future, you can always change the patch comment (in the patch itself before ---/+++ lines start). However, commit message should stay for historical reasons.

If you do this, I would have to look no further but Git and would know the state of the feature at any point of time. Otherwise, I would have to look at Git, Gerrit, Trac and/or SBM to put together the whole picture.

Thanks,
Dragan

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

1. MaxSegmentSize set in MBIM USB descriptor. The value is currently hardcoded as 4064 in Linux kernel USB stack. Kernel will have difficulties to access NV if we want to make this configurable. Besides, different RATs use different EFS/NV to store the MTU. I will propose to create a new Sierra NV "MBIM_MTU" to set the MTU used in MBIM USB descriptor. This NV will be cached in USB descriptor and a USB sysfs can be used to set it just like how VID/PID is set from user space.
2. MTU returned in QMI_WDS_GET_RUNTIME_SETTINGS (QBI_CID_IP_CONFIGURATION), This is RAT dependent and derived from several RAT related MTU NVs. AT command is required to set these NVs (plus the MBIM_MTU NV).

- MaxSegmentSize set in MBIM USB descriptor. The value is currently hardcoded as 4064 in Linux kernel USB stack. Kernel will have difficulties to access NV if we want to make this configurable. Besides, different RATs use different EFS/NV to store the MTU. I will propose to create a new Sierra NV "MBIM_MTU" to set the MTU used in MBIM USB descriptor. This NV will be cached in USB descriptor and a USB sysfs can be used to set it just like how VID/PID is set from user space.

- MTU returned in QMI_WDS_GET_RUNTIME_SETTINGS (QBI_CID_IP_CONFIGURATION), This is RAT dependent and derived from several RAT related MTU NVs. AT command is required to set these NVs (plus the MBIM_MTU NV).

comments.message: Yes , will fix it.
Printing in the interrupt handler is not good idea. I know that these prints were there before, but it would be good idea to remove then.
Ok, agree it.

Use and purpose of wake_n_waked is confusing. I think that the intention is to limit overuse of wake_lock/unlock . However, this flag is global, it is not atomic and I believe that there is no need to use it. If you would like to check if wake_lock exist, it would be better to use wake_lock_active or has_wake_lock. This way, kernel will take care of non-atomic issues and there is no danger of race conditions.

There are several places where wake_n_waked is used, and we can get rid of it.

Wake_n_waked has thress purpose:
1.  indicate the current WAKE_N pin state
2 .  limit overuse of wake_lock/unlock 
3.  decide to vote XO or not.

I can find out current state of the pin by reading it, and this flag becomes redundant in this case. The use of this flag is dangerous, because it is not atomic and we can run into race condition if this flag is read elsewhere, while IRQ is executing. I still think that we do not need it, please consider using wake_lock_active or has_wake_lock .
I think we can get rid of SWISTOP which does not have matching SWISTART.
I will check it.

Patch Set 1:

This App kernel change is for MaxSegmentSize configuration.

- MaxSegmentSize set in MBIM USB descriptor. The value is currently hardcoded as 4064 in Linux kernel USB stack. Kernel will have difficulties to access NV if we want to make this configurable. Besides, different RATs use different EFS/NV to store the MTU. I will propose to create a new Sierra NV "MBIM_MTU" to set the MTU used in MBIM USB descriptor. This NV will be cached in USB descriptor and a USB sysfs can be used to set it just like how VID/PID is set from user space.

- MTU returned in QMI_WDS_GET_RUNTIME_SETTINGS (QBI_CID_IP_CONFIGURATION), This is RAT dependent and derived from several RAT related MTU NVs. AT command is required to set these NVs (plus the MBIM_MTU NV).

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

Dragan, corrected the comments on behalf of Dube.
SIERRA_USB_COMPOSITION is used to mark any code changes related to USB composition (AT/DM/NMEA/OSA/ECM/RMNET/USB audio/ADB etc.).

Please review again.

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I've took a look at the SBM 14027, and it looks like the requirement is to remove messages. I looked at the changes, and the messages are going to be printed if CONFIG_SIERRA_USB_COMP is not defined. The comment indicates that the messages could be removed. If that's the case, I would suggest removal of these messages altogether (there is no need for conditional compilation).

If you want to keep the code, I would suggest you make pr_none macro, which will do nothing:

#define pr_none(...)

This way, prints will stay where they are, but there will be no output from these statements.

--Dragan

Patch Set 1:

Hi Dragan,

Yes currently the printing of these msgs are controlled by CONFIG_SIERRA_USB_COMP. Reasons:
1. Our principle of changing QTI code is to minimize the changes by compile switch. This is more a mark than a conditional compilation. Put it another way we have no condition to remove define of CONFIG_SIERRA_USB_COMP for our products.
2. We have been doing this for all our QTI platforms and products in both modem and apps side by disabling some code with compile switch (XXX_SIERRA_YYY). This would give us a clear clue of what we have changed on QTI code by searching key word 'SIERRA' and that benefits us a lot. This somehow became our ground rule to maintain QTI platform based products and we cannot afford breaking this.
3. Your suggestion looks sane.But as i said above we need consistency.

Hence I insist the changes.

Patch Set 1:

Dragan, please take another look. We will need to apply this soon because this is already in QTI Linux and we need to sync them for next Yocto tag.
Thanks.

Patch Set 1:

I understand that QCOM said that these are warning messages, but the code does not look like it. For example:
* CONFIG_SIERRA_USB_COMP removes both pr_info and pr_err messages. If these messages are not important, these should be turned into pr_info.
* The code clearly returns the error after the messages were printed. So, the conditions do not reflect exactly what QCOM developers communicated to us.

However, the most important question is the following: would there be any situation where we are going to use this kernel , but CONFIG_SIERRA_USB_COMP would not be defined? The reason I'm raising this question is the potential to have these messages show up again (it does not look like CONFIG_SIERRA_USB_COMP is generic SWIR switch, CONFIG_CHANGED_BY_SWIR would be).

Thanks,
Dragan

Patch Set 1:

1. All the change we do is to avoid printing redundant messages in console since we receive complaint on that. Even we change pr_err to pr_info the printing still there so it's not an option for us
2. We confirmed with QTI that even the function returns err, actually it doesn't matter. There might be something that need to be optimized by QTI by removing the print and err return. But it's not in our scope. What we do is to prevent this from being printed without breaking anything by QTI's confirmation.
3. as i said CONFIG_SIERRA_USB_COMP is more a code change mark/indication than a compile switch. I don't think we will ever undefine/disable this switch. It has to be there for the life cycle of the product, as long with other CONFIG_SIERRA_xxx. Actually initially we use one single CONFIG_SIERRA for all SWI changes, then we think it would be more meaningful to break it into different areas. That is where we are now.

Patch Set 1:

If these switches must all be enabled for the lifetime of the product, why not having it under the same name (like you had it before)? This way it is really confusing, and some day, someone will turn one of the switches off independently and this (or other code) will break.

What I would do is the following:
* Anything that would be for the lifetime of the product I would put under SWIR_LIFETIME ot SWIR_NO_FEATURE (or something similar) to indicate that code has nothing to do with particular feature, but the code change.
* For anything that could be turned on/off independently, I would use meaningful conditional compilation flag names which are feature related.

Thanks,
Dragan

I spent some time trying to figure out what is the source of this patch, and I could not pinpoint one. I went through numerous branches in Code Aurora, Yocto Linux, QTI Linux and all of these are different. However, it appears to be that QTI Linux is the closest match, and based on this:
* arch/arm/mach-msm/cpuidle.c - not all changes were transferred
* arch/arm/mach-msm/pm-8x60.c - not all changes were transferred
* arch/arm/mach-msm/pm.h - not all changes were transferred
* drivers/gpio/Kconfig - contains changes which logically belong to arch/arm/mach-msm/Kconfig

I could not find commit(s) in Code Aurora which deal with this issue, and it would be good to pinpoint one. This will allow us to make sure that we did not miss anything (even though this patch works).

We need to have read-only rootfs. We also need to support devices with smaller flash and RAM footprint. SQUASHFS would be ideal candidate, because it is well debugged, small, fast and compresses exceptionally well (more than 50% compression ratio on binary files). This way we will not only satisfy rootfs read-only requirement, we would also satisfy smaller flash/RAM support requirement.

Hi Bertrand,

As we know that the change in MDM9615.c is missed in the patch "0011-SBM-13658-r20197-AR7WP7-I2S-BCLK-clock-is-incorrect-.patch".

And is the change of audio router path necessary？

Uploaded patch set 2.

Patch Set 2:

Hi Yoking, Traving,

The routing update is necessary to make I2S secondary channel work.
In the 3.4 version, real back-ends like "SEC_I2S_RX" should be connected to fake BE "BE_OUT", and same thing for "SEC_I2S_TX" for "BE_IN" respectively.
If this link is not present, aplay / arec fail with error such as "MDM9615 Media1 no valid playback route from source to sink".

On this latest patch, there is some more routing rules integrated from msm-3.4 @ git://codeaurora.org/quic/le/kernel/msm .

BR,
Bertrand
Uploaded patch set 3.

Hi Bertrand,

I take note of you adding CS-Voice host item in the DAI links for AR7/WP7. If we do any change of the DAIs we need to update the hardware ID when setting the audio "path av_path_config() " in the file "sierra\av\av_config.c"

Patch Set 3:

Hi Traving,

I do not have access to the SVN where this file is located, but obtained a copy of 'av_config.c' indirectly.
If kernel changes from Gerrit are ported to the kernel managed by SVN, I suppose this file could be changed at the same time.

Since "msm-pcm-host-voice.c" is present in the SVN kernel, I also suppose there is support for Voice tappoints, so adding this feature should be fine.

As for compatibility, since these PCM DAIs (4 voice tappoints) are last (from a user-space point of view), numbering of older ones stay the same. It is also only adding amix commands. So as far as I can tell, it shouldn't break swiapp.

Do you agree, or did I miss something in this file ?

Thanks,
Bertrand
